awd_titl_txt: CAREER: CPS: Internet of Wearable E-Textiles for Telemedicine
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER project aims to translate the smart electronic textile (e-textile) technologies to fill the need for telemedicine. For example, there are around 10 million individuals across the globe who live with Parkinson's disease. They are majorly elderly patients who experience tremors, rigidity, slowness of movement, and difficulties in walking and driving. Despite their disabling condition, they need to make periodic visits to clinics for progressive checks and interventions. The project specifically targets improving treatments for patients with deep brain stimulation (DBS) implants because specialized neurologists find DBS treatments very complex and time consuming. It is very important for the doctors to personalize the electrical stimulations for each and every patient. The proposed research establishes an intelligent infrastructure in patients' homes so that patients, without visiting clinics, could independently perform a medical screening consisting of movement exercises such as finger tapping, hand flipping, toe tapping, and foot stomping. Moreover, the system builds upon modern internet-of-things technologies to keep neurologists in the loop to execute telemedicine interventions.  

The project will result into an in-home, wearable internet-of-things hub (referred to as "IoT-Hub") consisting of smart e-textiles such as e-gloves, e-socks, and companion computing devices for data analytics, storage, and communications to the cloud servers of hospitals. IoT Hub will have unique features to translate the medical care from hospitals to homes: 1) the measurements of movement symptoms with a medical-grade precision through sensors woven into e-gloves and e-socks, 2) the patient-friendly interface driven by intelligent close-loop algorithms running on tablet computers, and 3) clinical data analytics for neurologists to make data-driven informed decision on DBS treatments. The proposed IoT-Hub closes the knowledge gap between the areas of IoT, healthcare, smart textiles, and patient-centered design - all of which require interdisciplinary scientific discoveries and innovations.

This project will have a potentially profound impact on the growing number of elderly patients living with Parkinson's disease or other neurological conditions. Intelligent algorithms for wearable embedded systems, e-textile designs and circuits,  and de-identified telemedicine data will be broadly disseminated to the scientific community. The PI has developed a unique IoT curriculum at URI that involves a series of design-centered activities; an IoT hack-a-thon for entrepreneurial thinking; and awearable IoT course for university students to learn innovating personalized health and wellness solutions; and wearable engineering program to engage high school students in hands-on engineering activities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Overview

Over the course of the NSF CAREER Project conducted at the Wearable Biosensing Lab, University of Rhode Island, significant progress has been made in the field of remote patient monitoring, particularly in monitoring the movement symptoms of Parkinson's disease (PD). The project's primary goal was to design a user-friendly and effective remote monitoring device to empower individuals with PD to assess their symptoms from the comfort of their homes.

Intellectual Merit

The project began with the development of prototypes of smart textile wearables, including gloves and shoes. These prototypes evolved into sophisticated versions with refined designs, wearable electronics, and an Internet of Things (IoT) framework. The innovation involved novel methods for designing textile sensors and integrating them into everyday garments to monitor physiological and subtle body movement signals.

Smart gloves were a key focus, designed to improve the accuracy of sensing PD motor symptoms such as slowness of movement, rigidity, and tremors. Smart shoes were also introduced, equipped with pressure sensors and an inertial measurement unit (IMU) to monitor lower limb symptoms. These wearables were integrated into a comprehensive Wearable IoT ecosystem, enabling seamless sensing and communication between wearable sensors and cloud platforms.

The wearable electronics modules within the smart gloves and shoes underwent iterative design enhancements to achieve miniaturization and power efficiency, thus extending battery life. To facilitate real-world deployment in homes, challenges related to network connectivity, data transmission, latency, and remote interactions were effectively addressed through fog and edge computing frameworks.

The smart textile wearables were put to the test through in-home feasibility studies involving people with Parkinson's disease. Prior to human studies, extensive user-centered research, including participatory design, was conducted to address real-world challenges. These efforts significantly improved wearable design and patient interactions with the system. Human studies, including healthy individuals for benchmarking and characterization, in-lab studies with PD patients, and in-home studies, evaluated system performance across various domains such as reliability, usability, interoperability, connectivity, and user-friendliness.

Broader Impacts

The project resulted in the completion of five PhD dissertations and five MS theses, covering topics related to smart textiles, wearable sensors, signal processing, body sensor networks, smart and digital health, and the internet of things. Notably, one PhD student supported by the NSF CAREER initiative established a startup, EchoWear, focused on digital health technologies, while others pursued careers in academia or industry.

Numerous scientific publications and conference presentations have disseminated the promising outcomes of the CAREER project. Several students received awards and grants for their research contributions. The project also extended its impact to undergraduate students, providing research experiences and opportunities through URI undergraduate research grants. More than 13 STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) activities introduced K-12 students to paper circuits, electronic textiles, hardware, and coding.

A new course on Wearable Internet of Things was developed and delivered to undergraduate and graduate students, offering hands-on experience in designing wireless wearable devices. Additionally, five HealthHacks (regional hack-a-thons) events were organized to foster innovation and creativity among college students, with many themes centered around health and wellness.

The project maintained meaningful connections with local communities directly affected by Parkinson's disease and aging. Collaborations with clinical institutions, local industries, and educational partners enriched the project's scope. These partnerships included Rhode Island Hospital, Butler Hospital, the Rhode Island School of Design, the URI Department of Textiles, and URI's faculty of Kinesiology and Physical Therapy. Local startup companies also joined forces to test their innovations in clinical populations.

In terms of infrastructure, the project led to the establishment of new physical assets, including a technical embroidery machine and a 3D knitting machine to support smart textile design at URI. These achievements have positioned the Wearable Biosensing Lab as an integral part of Rhode Island's textile innovation ecosystem.

Summary

In summary, the NSF CAREER Project at the University of Rhode Island has made significant strides in the development of wearable technologies for monitoring PD symptoms. These advancements promise remote assessments, improved patient comfort, and usability. The project's impact extended to students, local communities, and collaborative partners, fostering innovation and enhancing healthcare possibilities. The journey continues towards a future of empowered individuals taking control of their well-being.

 


Last Modified: 09/26/2023
Modified by: Kunal Mankodiya
